title: Box Breathing (4×4)
summary: A 2–5 minute breathing pattern to reduce arousal and regain control.
when_to_avoid: If breath-holding causes dizziness (switch to paced breathing).
If you have severe breathing difficulty, seek medical help.
micro_script: Let’s do 4 slow cycles together. I’ll count with you.
embedding_text: Box Breathing (4×4). Use when: stress spike; panic symptoms; racing thoughts; before a difficult conversation. Steps: Inhale 4s; Hold 4s; Exhale 4s; Hold 4s; Repeat 4 cycles. Time: 2–5 minutes. Setting: home/work/public. Effort: low. Privacy: high.

title: 5-4-3-2-1 Grounding
summary: A quick sensory grounding exercise to interrupt spiraling fear and bring you back to the present.
when_to_avoid: If focusing on senses increases distress, switch to slow counting or a brief walk.
steps: Name 1 thing you can taste or are grateful for
micro_script: We’re going to anchor in the room. I’ll guide you: 5 things you can see…
embedding_text: 5-4-3-2-1 Grounding. Use when: sudden anxiety; feeling unreal/detached; panic build-up; overwhelm in public. Steps: Name 5 things you can see; Name 4 things you can feel (touch); Name 3 things you can hear; Name 2 things you can smell; Name 1 thing you can taste or are grateful for. Time: 1–3 minutes. Setting: home/work/public. Effort: low. Privacy: high.

title: Worry Postponement (10-minute window)
summary: A CBT-style technique to reduce constant worry by scheduling it, not obeying it.
when_to_avoid: If the worry is about immediate danger, act now or seek help instead of postponing.
steps: Write the worry in one sentence
Set a timer for a later 10-minute 'worry window'
Return to the next small task in front of you
During the worry window, brainstorm 1–2 concrete next steps (if any)
micro_script: Let’s park this worry for later. We’ll give it time—just not right now.
embedding_text: Worry Postponement (10-minute window). Use when: looping worries; can't focus; doom-scrolling urge; bedtime worry. Steps: Write the worry in one sentence; Label it: 'Noted—worry brain'; Set a timer for a later 10-minute 'worry window'; Return to the next small task in front of you; During the worry window, brainstorm 1–2 concrete next steps (if any). Time: 5–10 minutes. Setting: home/work. Effort: medium. Privacy: high.

title: STOP Skill (Pause → Choose)
summary: A fast de-escalation move to prevent anger from turning into impulsive actions.
when_to_use: urge to send a harsh message
when_to_avoid: If you feel unsafe, prioritize leaving and seeking support.
steps: P: Proceed (choose the next wise step: step back, speak softer, or delay)
micro_script: Before we do anything, we pause. One breath. What’s your urge level from 0 to 10?
embedding_text: STOP Skill (Pause → Choose). Use when: anger escalation; argument starting; urge to send a harsh message; feeling disrespected. Steps: S: Stop (freeze your action); T: Take a slow breath; O: Observe (body, thoughts, urge level 0–10); P: Proceed (choose the next wise step: step back, speak softer, or delay). Time: 1–3 minutes. Setting: home/work/public. Effort: low. Privacy: high.

title: Time-Out Script (Respectful Exit)
summary: A short script to step away from conflict without escalating it.
when_to_avoid: If walking away could increase risk of harm, seek a safer setting/support.
steps: Do one calming skill (breathing, water, grounding)
micro_script: I care about this, and I’m too heated to talk well. I’m taking 20 minutes and I’ll come back.
embedding_text: Time-Out Script (Respectful Exit). Use when: heated conversation; voice getting loud; repeating the same point; feeling attacked. Steps: Say the script once, calmly; Physically step away (bathroom, short walk); Set a return time (10–30 minutes); Do one calming skill (breathing, water, grounding); Return or reschedule. Time: 2–10 minutes. Setting: home/work/public. Effort: low. Privacy: medium.

title: Cooling Down: Cold Water Reset
summary: A quick body-based reset to lower anger arousal (safe, simple).
when_to_avoid: Avoid if you have medical conditions where cold exposure is unsafe; use breathing instead.
steps: Run cool water over hands for 30–60 seconds
Or splash cool water on face briefly
Then choose one small next action (delay reply, write draft, short walk)
micro_script: Let’s cool the body first. Cool water + slow exhales, then we decide what to do.
embedding_text: Cooling Down: Cold Water Reset. Use when: hot face/heart racing; can't think straight; after conflict; preparing to respond. Steps: Run cool water over hands for 30–60 seconds; Or splash cool water on face briefly; Pair with 6 slow exhales; Then choose one small next action (delay reply, write draft, short walk). Time: 1–5 minutes. Setting: home/work. Effort: low. Privacy: medium.

title: Micro-Activation (2-minute start)
summary: A tiny behavioral activation step to break the 'stuck' feeling of sadness.
when_to_avoid: If you feel physically unwell, choose rest or seek medical advice.
steps: Pick one '2-minute' task (shower, drink water, open window, tidy one corner)
micro_script: We’re not fixing everything—just starting. What’s one 2-minute task you can do right now?
embedding_text: Micro-Activation (2-minute start). Use when: low energy; stuck in bed; no motivation; procrastination from heaviness. Steps: Pick one '2-minute' task (shower, drink water, open window, tidy one corner); Set a 2-minute timer; Do only the 2 minutes; Stop and acknowledge: 'I moved'; Optional: repeat once. Time: 2–5 minutes. Setting: home/work. Effort: low. Privacy: high.

title: Kind Inner Voice (Name → Normalize → Support)
summary: A self-compassion mini-practice to reduce self-criticism that amplifies sadness.
when_to_avoid: If this feels fake, start by using neutral language instead of positive language.
steps: Normalize: 'It makes sense I feel this'
Support: 'What would I say to a friend?'
Say one supportive line to yourself
micro_script: This is hard. It makes sense you feel this. Let’s talk to you like we’d talk to a friend.
embedding_text: Kind Inner Voice (Name → Normalize → Support). Use when: self-blame; feeling unworthy; after a mistake; rejection feelings. Steps: Name the feeling: 'This is sadness'; Normalize: 'It makes sense I feel this'; Support: 'What would I say to a friend?'; Say one supportive line to yourself; Take one slow breath. Time: 2–6 minutes. Setting: home/public/work. Effort: low. Privacy: high.

title: Connection Ping (Low-Effort Reach-Out)
summary: A small, low-pressure way to reduce isolation when you feel down.
when_to_avoid: Avoid contacting someone who is unsafe or who consistently hurts you; choose a safer person.
steps: Send a simple message: 'Hey, can you talk for 5 minutes?'
If no reply, choose a backup (another person or a calming skill)
After contact, do one small care action (water, food, short walk)
micro_script: You don’t have to explain everything. Just a small ping: 'Can you talk for 5 minutes?'
embedding_text: Connection Ping (Low-Effort Reach-Out). Use when: feeling alone; ruminating; missing someone; low mood. Steps: Pick one safe person; Send a simple message: 'Hey, can you talk for 5 minutes?'; If no reply, choose a backup (another person or a calming skill); After contact, do one small care action (water, food, short walk). Time: 1–5 minutes. Setting: home/public. Effort: low. Privacy: high.

title: Disgust Reset: Ground + Label
summary: A quick grounding and labeling practice to reduce the intensity of disgust and prevent avoidance spirals.
when_to_avoid: If nausea is severe or you feel faint, pause and prioritize physical safety.
steps: Place both feet on the floor
Describe neutrally what you notice (no judgments)
Choose next step: step back briefly or do a small clean-up action
micro_script: Let’s label it and ground. Disgust is a body alarm—it doesn’t have to run the whole moment.
embedding_text: Disgust Reset: Ground + Label. Use when: strong 'gross' reaction; irritation at mess/odors; social disgust/shame; intrusive disgust thoughts. Steps: Name it: 'This is disgust'; Place both feet on the floor; Do 3 slow exhales; Describe neutrally what you notice (no judgments); Choose next step: step back briefly or do a small clean-up action. Time: 1–4 minutes. Setting: home/work/public. Effort: low. Privacy: high.

title: Small Clean / Small Boundary
summary: A practical, contained action to reduce disgust without turning into perfectionism.
when_to_avoid: Avoid if it becomes endless cleaning; set a hard time limit.
steps: Clean only one defined area (e.g., one countertop)
Decide if you need a boundary (ask for help, close a door, move away)
micro_script: We’ll do a *small* contained clean—5 minutes—then we stop. Boundaries beat spirals.
embedding_text: Small Clean / Small Boundary. Use when: mess triggers; shared spaces; sensory sensitivity; need for control. Steps: Set a 5-minute timer; Clean only one defined area (e.g., one countertop); Stop when timer ends; Wash hands and breathe once; Decide if you need a boundary (ask for help, close a door, move away). Time: 2–10 minutes. Setting: home/work. Effort: low. Privacy: medium.

title: Values Shift: What Matters Here?
summary: A short ACT-style pivot from disgust to values-driven behavior (useful for social disgust/shame).
when_to_avoid: If the situation is genuinely unsafe, choose safety and distance first.
steps: Name the story: 'My mind is judging'
Ask: 'What matters to me in this moment?' (respect, kindness, health, honesty)
Do it in the smallest possible way
micro_script: Disgust can be loud. Let’s ask: what matters to you here—kindness, respect, health?
embedding_text: Values Shift: What Matters Here?. Use when: judgment thoughts; feeling 'contaminated'; social shame; avoidance urges. Steps: Name the story: 'My mind is judging'; Ask: 'What matters to me in this moment?' (respect, kindness, health, honesty); Pick one value-consistent action; Do it in the smallest possible way; Acknowledge effort. Time: 3–7 minutes. Setting: home/work/public. Effort: medium. Privacy: high.

title: Self-Compassion Break (30–90s)
summary: A quick compassion practice to restore warmth when you’re caring for others or feeling tender.
when_to_avoid: If it increases emotion too fast, switch to neutral grounding (counting breaths).
steps: Say: 'This is a moment of difficulty'
Say: 'I’m not alone—others feel this too'
Say: 'May I be kind to myself right now'
micro_script: Let’s give you a tiny dose of kindness too. Hand on chest—three short lines—one breath.
embedding_text: Self-Compassion Break (30–90s). Use when: feeling tender; supporting someone; emotional fatigue; after a hard conversation. Steps: Hand on chest (optional); Say: 'This is a moment of difficulty'; Say: 'I’m not alone—others feel this too'; Say: 'May I be kind to myself right now'; One slow breath. Time: 1–3 minutes. Setting: home/work/public. Effort: low. Privacy: high.

title: Supportive Message Template (Short + Clear)
summary: A simple template to express care without over-explaining.
when_to_avoid: Avoid sending long emotional paragraphs if you’re dysregulated; keep it short.
steps: Start with care: 'I’m thinking of you'
Offer a choice: 'Do you want advice or just listening?'
Offer one concrete help: 'I can call / bring food / sit with you'
micro_script: Try: 'I’m here. Do you want advice or just someone to listen? No pressure to reply.'
embedding_text: Supportive Message Template (Short + Clear). Use when: wanting to help; not sure what to say; checking on a friend; repair after conflict. Steps: Start with care: 'I’m thinking of you'; Offer a choice: 'Do you want advice or just listening?'; Offer one concrete help: 'I can call / bring food / sit with you'; Respect boundaries: 'No pressure to reply'. Time: 1–5 minutes. Setting: home/work/public. Effort: low. Privacy: high.

title: Caring with Boundaries (Yes/No/Maybe)
summary: A boundary skill to prevent burnout while staying kind.
when_to_avoid: Avoid making promises when exhausted; decide after rest if possible.
steps: List what you might do with conditions (Maybe)
micro_script: Caring counts more when it’s sustainable. Let’s choose one clear 'Yes' and one clear 'No'.
embedding_text: Caring with Boundaries (Yes/No/Maybe). Use when: over-giving; resentment building; people-pleasing; compassion fatigue. Steps: List what you *can* do (Yes); List what you *cannot* do (No); List what you might do with conditions (Maybe); Communicate one clear boundary; Schedule recovery time. Time: 3–8 minutes. Setting: home/work. Effort: medium. Privacy: high.

title: If–Then Plan (Implementation Intention)
summary: Turn anticipation into action by pre-deciding what you’ll do when a trigger happens.
when_to_avoid: Avoid overly complex plans; keep to 1–2 If–Then rules.
steps: Identify one trigger: 'If I start overthinking…'
Choose one action: '…then I will do 3 slow exhales + write the next step'
Do a tiny prep step now
micro_script: Let’s convert anticipation into a plan: If X happens, then you’ll do Y. Simple and strong.
embedding_text: If–Then Plan (Implementation Intention). Use when: nervous excitement; big day coming; performance anxiety; preparing for change. Steps: Identify one trigger: 'If I start overthinking…'; Choose one action: '…then I will do 3 slow exhales + write the next step'; Write it down; Mentally rehearse once; Do a tiny prep step now. Time: 3–8 minutes. Setting: home/work/public. Effort: medium. Privacy: high.

title: Two-Column Prep (Control vs Not-Control)
summary: A fast clarity exercise to focus your energy on what you can actually influence.
when_to_avoid: Avoid using this to suppress feelings; it’s for direction, not denial.
steps: Draw two columns: Control / Not Control
Pick 1 action from Control you can do today
Pick 1 acceptance phrase for Not Control
micro_script: Let’s split the world into two: what you control and what you don’t. One small action is enough.
embedding_text: Two-Column Prep (Control vs Not-Control). Use when: waiting for results; uncertainty; upcoming meeting; travel day. Steps: Draw two columns: Control / Not Control; List 3 items in each; Pick 1 action from Control you can do today; Pick 1 acceptance phrase for Not Control; Stop after 5 minutes. Time: 3–7 minutes. Setting: home/work. Effort: low. Privacy: high.

title: Future-Self Message (90 seconds)
summary: A brief visualization + note to reduce uncertainty and build confidence.
when_to_avoid: Avoid if visualization triggers anxiety; use a written checklist instead.
steps: Imagine tomorrow-you after the moment is over
Choose 1 line to repeat before the event
micro_script: Picture future-you who got through it. What helped? Write 3 lines for present-you.
embedding_text: Future-Self Message (90 seconds). Use when: before an event; starting a new habit; hope + nerves; preparation. Steps: Imagine tomorrow-you after the moment is over; Ask: 'What helped?'; Write 3 short lines to yourself; Choose 1 line to repeat before the event. Time: 2–5 minutes. Setting: home. Effort: low. Privacy: high.

title: Orienting Reset (Look Around)
summary: A quick reset for sudden surprise: orient to safety, then decide your next move.
when_to_avoid: If there’s real danger, prioritize getting to safety first.
steps: Turn your head slowly and look for 3 safe/neutral objects
Name your location out loud (or silently)
Feel your feet on the ground
Choose one next action (pause, ask a question, step away)
micro_script: We’re going to orient first: three objects, where you are, feet on ground, two slow exhales.
embedding_text: Orienting Reset (Look Around). Use when: startled; unexpected news; sudden loud event; feeling frozen. Steps: Turn your head slowly and look for 3 safe/neutral objects; Name your location out loud (or silently); Feel your feet on the ground; Take 2 slow exhales; Choose one next action (pause, ask a question, step away). Time: 1–3 minutes. Setting: home/work/public. Effort: low. Privacy: high.

title: Pause + One Clarifying Question
summary: A communication skill for surprises: pause, then ask one question before reacting.
when_to_avoid: Avoid long debates while triggered; keep it to one question.
steps: Repeat back what you heard in one sentence
Decide whether to respond now or later
micro_script: Let’s slow it down: one breath, then one question. Understanding first, reaction second.
embedding_text: Pause + One Clarifying Question. Use when: unexpected feedback; confusing message; sudden change of plans; feeling reactive. Steps: Pause for one breath; Say: 'I want to understand'; Ask one clarifying question; Repeat back what you heard in one sentence; Decide whether to respond now or later. Time: 1–5 minutes. Setting: work/public/home. Effort: low. Privacy: high.

title: 10-Second Body Scan
summary: A micro body check to unfreeze and regain control after surprise.
when_to_avoid: Avoid if scanning increases panic; use simple counting instead.
steps: One slow exhale longer than inhale
micro_script: Quick scan: shoulders, jaw, hands… one long exhale… what’s the next tiny step?
embedding_text: 10-Second Body Scan. Use when: feeling frozen; jaw tight; shoulders up; mind blank. Steps: Notice shoulders (drop them 10%); Unclench jaw; Relax hands; One slow exhale longer than inhale; Name one next step. Time: 1–2 minutes. Setting: home/work/public. Effort: low. Privacy: high.

title: Neutral Check-In (60 seconds)
summary: A simple check-in to understand what you need when you feel 'nothing' or flat.
when_to_avoid: If you feel unwell, prioritize basic care and seek medical advice if needed.
steps: Name: one need (rest, food, connection, movement)
Do one 2-minute action for that need
micro_script: Let’s do a quick check-in: energy, stress, one need, one tiny action.
embedding_text: Neutral Check-In (60 seconds). Use when: feeling numb; low motivation; autopilot; can't name emotion. Steps: Rate: energy 0–10; Rate: stress 0–10; Name: one need (rest, food, connection, movement); Do one 2-minute action for that need. Time: 1–3 minutes. Setting: home/work/public. Effort: low. Privacy: high.

title: Micro-Routine (Start of Day / Reset)
summary: A tiny routine that builds momentum when you’re neutral and drifting.
when_to_avoid: Avoid perfectionism—keep it to 3 steps max.
steps: Open a window / get light for 30 seconds
Write the next single task (one line)
micro_script: No big plan—just a reset: water, light, one task, two minutes.
embedding_text: Micro-Routine (Start of Day / Reset). Use when: starting the day; between tasks; feeling aimless; low drive. Steps: Drink a glass of water; Open a window / get light for 30 seconds; Write the next single task (one line); Start for 2 minutes. Time: 2–6 minutes. Setting: home. Effort: low. Privacy: high.

title: Curiosity Prompt (What’s True Right Now?)
summary: A gentle curiosity prompt to discover subtle feelings and needs without forcing it.
when_to_avoid: If introspection increases distress, switch to grounding or activity.
steps: 3) What’s one thing I need next?
micro_script: Let’s get curious without pressure—three short answers, then one small next step.
embedding_text: Curiosity Prompt (What’s True Right Now?). Use when: flat mood; can't access feelings; overthinking about being 'fine'; emotional disconnect. Steps: Answer 3 prompts (one sentence each):; 1) What’s happening around me?; 2) What’s happening in my body?; 3) What’s one thing I need next?; Pick one small action. Time: 2–5 minutes. Setting: home/work. Effort: low. Privacy: high.

title: Savoring (30–60 seconds)
summary: A micro practice to amplify joy and store it in memory.
when_to_avoid: If you’re in a risky situation, focus on safety first.
steps: Name what’s good in one sentence
micro_script: Let’s let this land. Name one good thing, notice three details, one breath.
embedding_text: Savoring (30–60 seconds). Use when: good moment; small win; pleasant sensation; gratitude. Steps: Name what’s good in one sentence; Notice 3 details (sight/sound/body); Take one slow breath; Say: 'Let this land'; Optional: capture it (note/photo). Time: 1–2 minutes. Setting: home/work/public. Effort: low. Privacy: high.

title: Share the Win (1 message)
summary: A quick social joy skill: share a win to strengthen connection.
when_to_avoid: Avoid sharing with someone who often undermines you; choose a safe person.
steps: Send one short message about the win
Add a simple feeling word (proud, relieved, excited)
micro_script: Send one line: 'Small win: ___ . Feeling ___.' That’s it.
embedding_text: Share the Win (1 message). Use when: celebration; motivation boost; bonding; after progress. Steps: Pick one safe person; Send one short message about the win; Add a simple feeling word (proud, relieved, excited); Stop—no need to justify. Time: 1–5 minutes. Setting: home/public. Effort: low. Privacy: high.

title: Joy Anchor (Link it to a habit)
summary: Use a joyful moment to reinforce a healthy habit by linking them.
when_to_avoid: Avoid making huge commitments; choose a tiny habit.
steps: Link it to a joy cue (music, tea, sunlight)
Write the rule: 'After X, I do Y'
micro_script: Let’s anchor this good feeling into a tiny habit: after X, I’ll do Y—just 2 minutes.
embedding_text: Joy Anchor (Link it to a habit). Use when: building habits; staying consistent; making routines easier; after a good day. Steps: Pick a tiny habit (2 minutes); Link it to a joy cue (music, tea, sunlight); Write the rule: 'After X, I do Y'; Do it once today; Celebrate briefly. Time: 2–6 minutes. Setting: home/work. Effort: medium. Privacy: high.
